expanded_description: Horizontal and vertical lines create special cases in inequality graphing. Unlike slanted lines, these boundaries are parallel to the axes and divide the plane into simple regions: above/below for horizontal lines, and left/right for vertical lines. Understanding these cases is essential for graphing systems and for real-world constraints like 'height must be at least 48 inches' or 'age must be less than 65 years.'

core_concept.principle: For horizontal lines: $y > b$ shades above the horizontal line $y = b$; $y < b$ shades below. For vertical lines: $x > a$ shades to the right of the vertical line $x = a$; $x < a$ shades to the left. Use solid lines for $\leq$ or $\geq$, dashed lines for $<$ or $>$, just as with slanted lines.
core_concept.explanation: Think of horizontal boundaries as floors and ceilings. $y > 3$ means 'above the 3rd floor'—everything higher than that level. $y \leq -2$ means 'at or below the basement level -2.' Vertical boundaries are like east-west boundaries: $x > 5$ means 'east of the line x=5,' while $x < 5$ means 'west of that line.'

sections.introduction: Before graphing inequalities, let's review the equations of horizontal and vertical lines.

key_concept.definition:
• Horizontal line: $y = b$ (all points have the same y-coordinate)
• Vertical line: $x = a$ (all points have the same x-coordinate)
These lines are perpendicular to each other and parallel to the axes.
key_concept.context: These are the simplest lines to graph and their inequality versions are equally straightforward.

sections.introduction: Horizontal inequalities involve comparing y to a constant. The boundary is a horizontal line, and shading is above or below.

key_concept.definition:
For horizontal inequalities:
• $y > b$: shade **above** the horizontal line $y = b$ (dashed for $>$, solid for $\geq$)
• $y < b$: shade **below** the horizontal line $y = b$ (dashed for $<$, solid for $\leq$)
The line itself is horizontal at $y = b$.
key_concept.context: These inequalities represent conditions like 'height greater than 48 inches' or 'temperature below freezing.'

sections.introduction: Vertical inequalities involve comparing x to a constant. The boundary is a vertical line, and shading is to the right or left.

key_concept.definition:
For vertical inequalities:
• $x > a$: shade **to the right** of the vertical line $x = a$ (dashed for $>$, solid for $\geq$)
• $x < a$: shade **to the left** of the vertical line $x = a$ (dashed for $<$, solid for $\leq$)
The line itself is vertical at $x = a$.
key_concept.context: These inequalities represent conditions like 'ages greater than 18' or 'quantities less than 100.'

sections.introduction: Real-world constraints often involve both horizontal and vertical conditions, creating rectangular regions.

introduction_image.alt: Region defined by x between 2 and 5 and y between 1 and 4
introduction_image.caption: Figure 8.2.22: Combined horizontal and vertical boundaries.

key_concept.definition: When we combine horizontal and vertical inequalities, we get rectangular regions. For example, $x > 2$, $x < 5$, $y > 1$, and $y < 4$ defines the interior of a rectangle. Including equality gives boundaries.
key_concept.context: These regions model constraints like 'x must be between 10 and 20' and 'y must be between 5 and 15'—common in optimization problems.

sections.introduction: Horizontal and vertical inequalities model many real-world constraints involving limits, ranges, and thresholds.

introduction_image.alt: Real-world examples: height requirement, age limit, temperature range
introduction_image.caption: Figure 8.2.29: Real-world applications.

key_concept.definition:
Real-world applications include:
• Height requirements: $h \geq 48$ inches (vertical? Actually height is usually y, so horizontal inequality if height is on y-axis)
• Age limits: $a \geq 18$ (if age is on x-axis, vertical inequality)
• Temperature ranges: $20 \leq T \leq 30$ (horizontal if T on y-axis)
• Budget constraints: $x \leq 100$ (vertical if x is quantity)
key_concept.context: Which axis a variable goes on depends on how you set up the graph, but the inequality type is determined by which variable is being constrained.

summary: Horizontal and vertical inequalities are special cases in inequality graphing. For horizontal inequalities of the form $y > b$ or $y \geq b$, shade above the horizontal line $y = b$; for $y < b$ or $y \leq b$, shade below. For vertical inequalities of the form $x > a$ or $x \geq a$, shade to the right of the vertical line $x = a$; for $x < a$ or $x \leq a$, shade to the left. Use dashed lines for strict inequalities ($<$, $>$) and solid lines for inclusive inequalities ($\leq$, $\geq$). Combining horizontal and vertical inequalities creates rectangular regions, which are useful for modeling real-world constraints like height requirements, age limits, temperature ranges, and budget limits. When graphing, pay careful attention to which variable is being constrained—$y$ inequalities are horizontal, $x$ inequalities are vertical. These simple boundaries form the foundation for more complex systems of inequalities and linear programming applications.
